description: Dispute over whether items are fixtures or personal property
facts: George sold his house to Helen
George had a freestanding bookshelf that was not attached to any wall
The bookshelf rested on the floor and could be easily moved
George removed the bookshelf before closing, claiming it was personal property
Helen claims all items in the house should have remained
asp_facts: property_claim(claim4). claimant(claim4, helen). respondent(claim4, george). claim_type(claim4, fixture_determination). property_type(claim4, house). item_type(claim4, bookshelf). attachment_method(claim4, freestanding). custom_built(claim4, no). easily_movable(claim4, yes). contract_mention(claim4, no). removed_before_closing(claim4, yes).
question: Is the bookshelf a fixture that should have remained with the property?
rationale: The three-part fixture test examines: (1) annexation - it was freestanding with no attachment; (2) adaptation - not custom-built for the space; (3) intent - easily movable suggests temporary placement. The bookshelf is personal property and George properly removed it.
